question: Discuss eight problems of agricultural development in Nigeria and suggest one possible solution to each of the problems
answer:
The problems of agricultural development in Nigeria and one possible solution each are

(i) Inadequate land: The type of land tenure system, increasing population in Nigeria and deforestation do not make land available for agriculture. Solution: The government should implement the land use decree of 1978

(ii) Poor storage and processing facilities: These facilities are inadequate, costly, scarce and these eventually reduce the quality and quantity of agricultural produce. Solution: Government should provide storage and processing facilities at subsidised rate.

(iii) Lack of finance: Farmers do not have access to loan. They lack collateral security and the interest rate is very high. These prevent development of agriculture. Solution: Interest rate charged by banks should be reduced so that farmers can borrow money.

(iv) Inadequate farm input: Farm inputs are also scarce, inadequate, expensive and most farmers lack the technical know - how to operate them hence low agricultural procutivity. Solution: Government should reduce the cost of of farm inputs.

(v) Poor transportation Network; Most farms are not easily accessible; roads are bad coupled with lack of vehicles and high cost of transportation and these hinder agricultural development. Solution: Government Should construct good roads in rural areas

(vi) Lack of basic amenities: Social amenities like electricity, pipe borne water, health care services etc are lacking in rural areas and these affect agricultural production. Solution: Government through DFRRI should provide these amenities in rural areas.

(vii) Inadequate agricultural education and extension services: Most farmers are illiterate, conservative and crude. Extension officers are inadequate and inefficient hence, low agricultural productivity. Solution: Mass literacy campaign should be launched where farmers can be trained in modern method of farming.

(viii) Poor marketing system: There is no organised marketing system for farm produce. Produce are sold immediately after harvesting. Solution: Government agencies should buy produce from farmers and store for future consumption.

question: a) i) What Is farm surveying ? (ii) Outline the importance of farm surveying. (b) List and discuss four survey equipment commonly used in the farm.
answer:
(a)(i) Farm surveying is a series of activities, mainly measurements, performed in the field to locate the farm land, delineate its boundaries, determine its size and produce a map of the farmland.

(ii) Importance of farm surveying e: include: (i) it helps to know the size of the farm. (ii) It helps in the production of the soil map of the farm. (iii) It ensures good planning of the farmstead. (iv) It demarcates the farm boundaries and identifies its features and the location.

(b) Four surveying equipment commonly used in the farm are: (i) Ranging pole (ii) Gunter's chain (iii) Measuring tape (iv) al Prismatic compass.

(i) Ranging poles: These are wood or metal poles used in marking spots or stations during surveying.

(ii) Gunter's chain: This is a surveyor's chain of 100 links. 22 meters long used to measure a piece of land.

(iii) Measuring tapes: These are used in taking short or detailed measurements

(iv) Prismatic compass: This is used to measure horizontal angles between a reference median and a point of interest in order to find the orientation of the point and its bearing.

question: (a) Mention two major elements of climate. (b) Discuss six ways by which climate and vegetation influence soil formation
answer:
(a) Two major elements of climate are: (i) Rainfall (ii) Temperature.

(b) Six ways by which climate and vegetation influence soil formation are: (i) Rainfall through its running water helps to weather rocks. (ii) The chemical action of water also helps to break rock to form soil (iii) Expansion and contraction of rocks due to high temperature helps to break-down rocks. (iv) The roots of trees in the forest helps to break down rocks to form soil. (v) Wind carrying rock particles breaks other rocks to form soil (vi) Fallen leaves from trees decay to form humus in the soil.

question: (a) Explain the term soil structure and state its importance in agriculture. (b) State four properties each of clay and sandy soil.
answer:
(a) Soil structure: This refers to the ways in which the different particles of the soil are packed or arranged. lt also refers to the shape and arrangement of primary particles to form compound. Examples are crumb, plate-like,prismatic and spheroidal structures.

The Importance of soil structure include: It determines the (i) level of aeration of the soil. (ii) the fertility of the soil. (iii) the amount of living organisms in the soil

(b) (i) Four properties of sandy soil are: (i) It is coarse and large - grained. (ii) It is loose and gritty. (iii) It has large air pores hence. it supports aeration. (iv) It cannot form. ribbon or castes since it is not sticky when wet.

(b)(ii) Four properties of clay soil are: (i) clay soil is smooth and finely grained (ii) It has small airpores. (iii) It is sticky, when wet. (iv) It supports erosion and water logging.

question: (a) State the laws of Mendel (b) Discuss three advantages and two disadvantages of: (i) introduction-, (ii) selection in crop improvement
answer:
(a) The laws of Mendel are in two parts: (i) Mendel's first law of segregation of genes states that genes are responsible for the development of the individual and that they are independently transmitted from one generation to another without undergoing any alteration.

(ii) Mendel's second law of independent assortment of genes states that each character behaves as a separate unit and is inherited independently of any other character.

(b)(i) Three advantages of introduction in crop improvement are (i) it helps to introduce new varieties of crops to the new area. (ii) It may enhance greater productivity. (iii) It may perform better if conducive climatic conditions are present in the new area.

(ii) Two disadvantages of introduction in crop improvement are (i) It may introduce new diseases to the new area. (ii) The new plants may not adapt to the new area. (iii)

Three advantages of selection in crop improvement are: (i) It reduces the spread of .ests and diseases. (ii) It ensures that only the best naturally available crop is grown. (iii) Crops with desired qualitities are selected .

While two of the disadvantages of selection in crop improvement are: (i) It is tedious and time (ii) requires expertise which may not be easily available.

question: (a) What is rangeland ? (b) Discuss seven practices of management and improvement of rangeland
answer:
(a) Rangeland refers to a piece of land containing natural grasses, legumes and herbs which can be eaten by tam animals. In other words, it is a natural pasture,

(b) Seven practices of management and improvement of rangeland are: (i) Burning to encourage regrowth of grasses. (ii) Fencing to ensure rotational grazing. (iii) Weeding to speed up the growth  of pastures. (iv) Fertilization to increase yield of pasture. (v) Pest and disease control to ensure rapid growth of Pasture. (vi) Irrigation to ensure continuous growth of pasture especially during the dry season (vii) Adequate stocking to prevent overgrazing

question: Explain how each of the following practices can bring about high yield from a fish pond: (a) deweeding: (b) desilting (c) supplementary feeding (d) fertilization.
answer:
Practices which can bring about high yields from a fish pond include:

(a) Deweeding: This is the removal of weedy pond. It allows the dissolution of oxygen in water and the penetration of sunlight to the bottom of pond which aids the growth of fish food (planktons). It also prevents the built up of pests and diseases.

(b) Desilting: This is the remove of l silts from water to make the water to be clean. It promotes easy movement of fish within the water and prevent Pollution of water.

(c) Supplementary feeding (i) It ensures the availability of balance feed for the fish and ensure'. rapid growth of fish. It promotes multiplication of fish through reproduction.

(d) Fertilization: It ensures the availability of nutrients for the growth of planktons and increases the rapid growth of fish

question: Enumerate eight functions of an extension agent in the life of a rural farmer
answer:
Eight functions of an extension agent in the life of a rural farmer are:

(i) Agricultural extension teaches improved practices to farmers in the cultivation, rearing and processing of crops and livestock.

(ii) It acts as an intermediary between farmers and research institutes.

(iii) It encourages farmers to increase productivity of food, cash crops and livestock.

(iv) It helps to collect and collate basic information relating to rural economy which are used for implementing certain programmes.

(v) It educates rural women in home management (vi) It helps to identify proper marketing channel to sell their products.

(vii) Agricultural extension helps to raise the standard of living of farmers. (viii) It helps to change people's attitude towards their problems.

question: (a) Explain the meaning of agricultural finance and agricultural credit. (b) Name six sources of agricultural credit available to the small-scale farmer (c) Mention six problems associated with agricultural credits.
answer:
Agricultural finance is the act of acquisition and use of capital in agriculture. It deals with the supply and demand for funds in the agricultural sector of the economy while agricultural credit is a repayable loan given to farmers with or without interest to enable them carry out their farm operation more efficiently.

(b) Sources of agricultural credit available to the small-scale farmer are: (i) Agricultural Banks like Nigerian Agricultural and Cooperative Bank (N.A.C.B.). (ii) Supervised Agricultural credit schemes. (iii) Thrift and saving societies. (iv) Self financing or personal savings.(v) Money lender. (iv) Cooperatives societies. (c) Six problems associated with Agricultural credits are: (i) High interest rate. (ii) Lack of collateral security. (iii) Diversion of loan by .borrowers. (iv) Long gestation periods, especially for plantation crops (v) High incidence of loan defaulters. (vi) Difficulties in recovering loan
